description_abstract: We develop the necessary theory in algebraic geometry to place Bayesian networks into the realm of algebraic statistics. This allows us to create an algebraic geometry--statistics dictionary. In particular,  we study the algebraic varieties defined by the conditional independence statements of Bayesian networks. A complete algebraic classification, in terms of  primary decomposition of polynomial ideals, is given for Bayesian networks on at most five random variables. Hidden variables are related to the geometry of  higher secant varieties. Moreover, a complete algebraic classification, in terms of  generating sets of polynomial ideals,   is given for Bayesian networks on at most three random variables and one hidden variable. The relevance of these results for  model selection is discussed.
